There were reports after that. These reports said it was not only about the 737 Max problem. It was not just about arguments with the FAA. All of these things made it bad for Muilenburg. Last week, Boeing had a big event. They launched a space capsule. But something went wrong with the launch.

text: The Chinese proverb is “be careful what you wish for”. My own adapted version is “be careful what you vote for”. I make no apology for having devoted so many columns to what on Thursday became the lost cause of Remain. The pro-European cause in this country has, alas, suffered from a colossal failure of leadership. The failure to make the case for our EU membership goes back a long way, as does the drip-drip of the vile anti-European campaign in the Murdoch press, and the obvious suspects in other sections of the media. The sequence of events was well brought out in Denis MacShane’s prophetic book Brexit – How Britain Will Leave Europe in 2015. (What lies in store is outlined both in MacShane’s latest volume, Brexiternity, and Sir Ivan Rogers’s recent magisterial lecture at Glasgow University.) As MacShane wrote in 2015: “The referendum on Europe is not on the benefits or cost of EU membership, but a wider protest about economic and social change which appears inside Britain to produce as many losers as winners.” It was always easy to blame “Brussels” for policies that became controversial, even when those policies were initiated by successive UK governments themselves. One of the leading perpetrators of lies about Europe was, of course, the Telegraph’s former Brussels correspondent himself: Boris Johnson. Johnson is such a master of what his putative hero Winston Churchill called “terminological inexactitudes” that nothing he claimed during the campaign or the morning of his victory can be taken at face value. “One-nation Conservatism”? Governing for the interests of those northerners who have “lent him their votes”? Pull the other one! How does that compare with his plans for deregulation, closer alignment with Trump’s America, and the opportunities for profiting from Brexit to which his financial backers look forward? As Rogers said in his Glasgow lecture, Johnson’s claim that we will “not suffer any downside in terms of market access into easily our biggest market for goods and services … is clearly untrue. It does not get any truer through endless repetition.” The nation has been the victim of a gigantic con trick on the part of the Leave campaign.
a2_text:
It is an old saying: "Be careful what you wish for." I think: "Be careful what you vote for."

I have written a lot about staying in the EU. Now, it is a lost cause. I am sorry. The people who wanted Britain to stay in the EU did not lead well.

For a long time, they did not explain why being in the EU was good. Some newspapers and TV channels said bad things about the EU. This went on for a long time.

Denis MacShane wrote a book in 2015. It was called "Brexit – How Britain Will Leave Europe." He said what would happen. He was right.

MacShane wrote that the vote about Europe was not really about the EU. It was about people who felt they were losing because of changes in Britain.

It was easy to blame the EU for bad things. But sometimes, the British government made those rules.

Boris Johnson lied about Europe. He used to work for a newspaper in Brussels. He is good at saying things that are not true.

Johnson says he will help everyone in Britain. He says he will help people in the north who voted for him. But he also wants to change rules and be more like America. His rich friends want to make money from Brexit.

Ivan Rogers said that Johnson is wrong. Johnson says that Britain will still sell things easily to Europe. Rogers said this is not true. Saying it again and again does not make it true.

The people who voted to leave the EU were tricked. The Leave campaign lied to them.

text: The nonsensical propaganda about “getting Brexit done” was finally too much for the counsellor in the British embassy in Washington who resigned recently because she could no longer face peddling a misleading line. But back to failures of leadership: Jeremy Corbyn’s failure was on an epic scale. Reputedly a Leaver himself, he made a huge mistake in thinking that, by equivocating over the referendum, he could somehow please those supposedly natural Labour voters in the Midlands and the north who had voted Leave in the referendum. The election showed that too many of them merely laughed in his face. It seems that the election was also a referendum on Corbyn. There has been, and will continue to be, endless speculation about the reasons why the electorate distrusted him even more than Johnson. But historically there seems to me a simple, fundamental cause, whatever the deficiencies in Corbyn personally. In the early 1980s the sensible centre of the Labour party fought the extreme left – then known as the Militant Tendency, not Momentum – and saw them off. The late Denis Healey played a crucial role, as did Neil Kinnock and Roy Hattersley. And the moderate left in Britain and continental Europe watched the failure of President Mitterrand’s experiment with “socialism in one country” between 1981 and 1983 and learned the lesson. Among those who learned the lesson was Mitterrand himself. Tony Blair and Gordon Brown also took note. Alas, this time the extreme left captured the Labour party, with the results we now see. For reasons that I fail to understand, Corbyn and his allies, such as Seumas Milne, believe that the EU is some kind of capitalist conspiracy. Despite the many doubts about Corbyn himself, if he had not equivocated and campaigned vigorously in favour of Remain and a referendum with no ifs or buts, there might well have been a hung parliament and deals which could have contained Corbyn’s wilder plans. Also, the hapless Jo Swinson should not have made the strategic mistake of ruling out the second referendum her party had previously espoused. However, we are where we are.
a2_text:
A woman worked at the British embassy in America. She helped tell people about Brexit. Brexit was when the UK left the European Union.

She thought the information about Brexit was not true. She did not want to tell people things that were not correct. So, she quit her job.

Now, let's talk about Jeremy Corbyn. He was a leader of the Labour party. He made a big mistake. Many people think he wanted the UK to leave the European Union.

He tried to please everyone about Brexit. He did not say clearly what he thought. People in some areas of England voted to leave the EU. Corbyn thought he could get their votes.

But many people did not trust him. They voted against him in the election. The election was also about whether people liked Corbyn.

Many people did not trust Corbyn more than they trusted Johnson. Johnson was another leader.

A long time ago, in the 1980s, there were different groups in the Labour party. One group was called the Militant Tendency. They had extreme ideas.

Other leaders in the Labour party stopped the Militant Tendency. These leaders were Denis Healey, Neil Kinnock, and Roy Hattersley.

At the same time, France had a leader named President Mitterrand. He tried new ideas. But they did not work well.

Other leaders like Tony Blair and Gordon Brown learned from this. They saw that extreme ideas can fail.

But this time, the extreme left group took over the Labour party. Now we see the results. Corbyn and his friends thought the European Union was bad. They thought it was a plan by rich people.

Many people did not trust Corbyn. But if he had clearly supported staying in the EU, things might be different. There might have been no clear winner in the election. Then, Corbyn's ideas might not have been possible.

Also, another leader, Jo Swinson, made a mistake. She said there would not be another vote on Brexit. Her party had wanted another vote before.

But now, things are the way they are. We cannot change the past.

text: The Brexit and Conservative party is going to “deliver” Brexit. But so far from “getting Brexit done”, the election result means that Brexit has only just begun. Is the British public bored by Brexit talk? I am sorry, but there is a lot more boredom in store, and goodness knows how much economic damage from leaving the single market – the creation of which was, ironically, considered by Kenneth Clarke as Margaret Thatcher’s greatest achievement. Happy Christmas!
a2_text:
Okay, here is the rewritten text at CEFR A2 level:

The Brexit party wants to finish Brexit. They say they will "deliver" it. But the election result means Brexit is not finished. It is just starting.

Are British people tired of talking about Brexit?  I am sorry, but there will be more talk about it.

We do not know how much money will be lost from leaving the single market. Kenneth Clarke thought Margaret Thatcher did a very good thing when she created the single market. It's funny because now the UK is leaving.

Happy Christmas!

text: As we wrap up the year, I thought it would be fun to look back at all the columns I have written for the Guardian and pull out the five stories that were my favorites. Why are these my favorites? Mostly because these stories captured the best and worst aspects of running a small business this year. Female-owned businesses: the US economy’s quiet success story A report earlier this year found that 42% of all firms are female-owned and women started 1,817 businesses a day in the past year. My daughter is currently watching Mad Men for the first time and was shocked at how women were treated in the workplace a mere 50 years ago. To me, that just shows how much things have changed. Unfortunately – as I also wrote here – the out-of-date attitudes of some men in positions of power continue to challenge female advancement and opportunities in the workplace. But, there’s still been a lot of progress. As I wrote: “The fact is that women have made significant gains not only in the workplace but in entrepreneurship. Of course there is still a long way to go to achieve equality. But, compared with the data from 10 or 20 years before, there’s no dispute that the environment continues to improve.” Unlimited vacation isn’t as crazy as it sounds – and it can save you money I like reporting on small business news, but I also enjoy sharing good tactics that can help small business owners grow. One of these tactics involves unlimited vacation. 2019 was a year of very tight unemployment and just about every small business owner I know struggled to find and keep good employees. So what about unlimited vacation? Don’t laugh. My report found that unlimited vacation plans can be a potential great benefit and not as costly or as risky as they may seem. As I wrote: “... the vacation benefits you offer should best suit the interests of your employees and your company’s culture. An unlimited paid time-off plan may not be the right thing for your business. But considering some of the potential financial benefits, you should at least be seriously considering it.” Could this be the worst cafe in the world? I know I’m supposed to cover American businesses, but this little restaurant in an out-of-the-way place in New Zealand was too irresistible to ignore. “Just how bad is the customer service at the Springfield Store and Cafe?” I wrote.
a2_text:
This year is ending. I want to talk about my favorite stories from the Guardian. I wrote many stories for them. I picked five stories.

These stories show the good and bad things about running a small business this year.

One story is about women who own businesses. These businesses are doing well in the US. A report said that 42% of all companies are owned by women. Women started 1,817 businesses every day last year.

My daughter is watching a TV show called Mad Men. It shows how women were treated at work 50 years ago. She was surprised. Things have changed a lot since then.

But some men in powerful jobs still have old ideas. This makes it hard for women to get better jobs. But women are still making progress.

I wrote that women are doing better at work and in business. We still need to do more to make things equal. But things are better than they were 10 or 20 years ago.

Another story is about unlimited vacation. It may sound strange, but it can save money. I like to write about small business news. I also like to share good ideas to help businesses grow.

One good idea is unlimited vacation. In 2019, it was hard to find and keep workers. Many small business owners had this problem.

So, what about unlimited vacation? It can be a good thing! It may not cost as much as you think.

I wrote that the vacation you offer should be good for your workers and your company. Unlimited vacation might not be right for every business. But it can save money, so you should think about it.

Another story is about a cafe. It might be the worst cafe in the world! I usually write about American businesses. But this cafe in New Zealand was too interesting to ignore. It was in a place that was far away.

I wrote, "How bad is the customer service at the Springfield Store and Cafe?"

text: “So bad that people have been reportedly chased out of the cafe and others were forced to leave in tears after being abused by staff members. So bad that the police have actually been called and so bad that some of the local residents boycott the restaurant. ‘It’s an embarrassment to our community,’ one resident said. ‘You don’t have to talk to too many people before you come across somebody who’s had a bad experience there. I want them gone – the whole town wants them gone.’” But what’s interesting is that the cafe continues to thrive. Why? It has decent food and its owner’s behavior draws curiosity. Sometimes even poorly run businesses can succeed, despite their best efforts to fail. Why ‘Slutty Vegan’ became a hit in Atlanta – a city known for its barbecue Speaking of peculiar businesses, this one caught my attention last January because what kind of crazy person sells vegan food in the epicenter of barbecue, Atlanta, Georgia? And kills it! It’s a smart entrepreneur named Pinky Cole, a food truck owner who opened her first brick-and-mortar vegan eatery called Slutty Vegan at the beginning of the year and saw more than 1,200 people line up outside its doors on its very first day. Combining great food with an even better name, Cole’s restaurant has been a hit in 2019, attracting celebrities such as Shaquille O’Neal. She’s also laying the plans for more locations in 2020. No, she will never get me to stop eating meat – but I have to admit it will be tough to resist a Fussy Hussy (it consists of a plant-based patty with vegan cheese, shredded lettuce, onion, pickle and vegan mayo on a Hawaiian bun) the next time I’m in town. What’s the dynamic demographic running America’s small businesses? Older people OK Boomer, you’re still in charge. I’m thrilled for all the female entrepreneurs who are finally making their mark, but can we still give a small shoutout to us old people? The fact is that America’s small businesses are still dominated by people in their 50s and 60s, and if you’re marketing to small businesses, you best not ignore this demographic.
a2_text:
Some people say this cafe is very bad.
People say they were chased out of the cafe.
Some people had to leave because they were crying.
The staff were not nice to them.
The police came to the cafe.
Some people who live nearby do not go to the cafe.
One person said it is bad for their town.
They said many people have had bad experiences there.
The person wants the cafe to close. They said everyone in the town wants that too.

But the cafe is still doing well. Why?
The food is good.
The owner does things that make people curious.
Sometimes a bad business can do well.

Let's talk about a strange business.
It is called "Slutty Vegan."
It is in Atlanta. Atlanta is a city famous for barbecue.
Why would someone sell vegan food there?

Pinky Cole is the owner.
She had a food truck.
Then she opened a restaurant called "Slutty Vegan."
On the first day, 1,200 people waited outside!

The food is good. The name is good too.
The restaurant became very popular in 2019.
Famous people like Shaquille O'Neal went there.
Pinky Cole wants to open more restaurants in 2020.

I will still eat meat.
But I might try a "Fussy Hussy."
It has fake meat, fake cheese, lettuce, onion, pickle, and fake mayonnaise.
It is on a sweet Hawaiian bun.

Who runs small businesses in America?
Older people are still in charge.
Many women are starting businesses. That is great!
But older people still run many small businesses.
If you want to sell things to small businesses, remember the older people.
Most owners are in their 50s and 60s.

text: According to a survey, 57% of small business owners were born between 1946 and 1964. Sure, millennials are taking over the workplace and will very soon (thank goodness) take over the world. But that’s not going to happen right away and in the meantime it’s the boomers who are still running the majority of our country’s small businesses. I wish I had the time to include more, but there’s eggnog to consume. So for now, have a great new year and see you in 2020 with more stories about and for small business owners. It’s going to be a busy and interesting year for us all.
a2_text:
Here is the text rewritten for CEFR A2 level:

A study says something interesting. 57% of people who own small shops were born between 1946 and 1964. These people are called "Boomers."

Younger people are starting to work more. They may own many things in the future. But it will take some time.

Now, the Boomers still own many small shops. They run most of the small shops in our country.

I want to say more. But I need to go now. I want to drink eggnog!

Happy New Year! See you in 2020. I will tell more stories about small shop owners then. It will be a busy and good year for everyone.

text: In a parallel political universe, Ofwat’s pricing framework for the English and Welsh water companies for the next five years would have been redundant before it was announced on Monday. Incoming Labour ministers would instead be inspecting their soon-to-be nationalised assets. None of that will now happen, so the key issue in a still-privatised world is different. Will any of the companies that have bleated behind the scenes about a “politicised” regulatory process dare to allege unreasonable harshness on the part of Ofwat? Will any appeal to the Competition and Markets Authority (CMA)? We’ll have to wait eight weeks – the permitted period for an appeal – to find out, but the likely suspects would be well advised to swallow their medicine. First, Ofwat’s review is pitched as the “toughest ever”, but so it had to be. Shareholders since privatisation in 1989 have enjoyed a dividend bonanza so this was always going to be a moment to lean in the opposite direction. That’s not evidence of politicisation; it’s just a recognition that regulation has been too lax. Ofwat’s new demands will strike most bill-payers as reasonable: lower returns on capital; a reduction in bills by £50 on average, ignoring inflation, over the next five years; and a 16% cut in leaks. Second, Ofwat has given some ground between its “draft” and “final” calculations. Companies, in aggregate, will be allowed about £1.5bn of extra expenditure to meet performance targets. The concession is not huge in the context of a £51bn spending programme, but it’s a softening. Third, the new regime will only look “tough” to the laggards, judged by efficiency. Note how the share price of Severn Trent, one of three companies that got top-of-the-class “fast track” status during Ofwat’s review, is within pennies of its all-time high. Its shareholders see little to frighten them. Fourth, an appeal to the CMA is not a one-way bet. The competition regulator is allowed to conclude that Ofwat should have been harder.
a2_text:
In another world of politics, things could be different. The plan for water companies in England and Wales might not be needed. This plan is from Ofwat, for the next five years.

Maybe new ministers from the Labour party would be looking at the water companies. They might be about to make them part of the government. But this is not happening now.

So, the important question is: will the water companies complain? They have said that Ofwat is being unfair. Will they say the plan is too hard? Will they ask the Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) to look at it?

We have to wait eight weeks to know. This is how long they have to ask for help. But the companies that might complain should be careful.

First, Ofwat says this is the "hardest" plan ever. It needs to be. Since 1989, the owners of the water companies have made a lot of money. So now, Ofwat wants to do the opposite. This is not unfair. It just means the rules have been too easy.

Most people who pay water bills will think the new plan is fair. It asks for less money for the companies. It will make bills cheaper by about £50 each year. This does not include inflation. And it wants 16% less water to leak.

Second, Ofwat has changed the plan a little bit. It will let the companies spend about £1.5 billion more. This will help them reach their goals. This is not a lot of money compared to the total spending of £51 billion. But it is a little easier for the companies.

Third, the new plan will only seem "hard" to the companies that are not good at their job. For example, Severn Trent is a good company. It got a "fast track" in Ofwat's plan. This means it is doing well. The price of its shares is very high. The owners of the company are not worried.

Fourth, asking the CMA for help is not easy. The CMA could say that Ofwat should have been even stricter. So, complaining to the CMA is a risk.

text: That thought ought to concentrate minds in the boardrooms of the four companies – Anglian, Northumbrian, Thames and Yorkshire – that are thought most likely to appeal. It’s time for them to accept that, in a privatised but regulated system, owners have to take a hit sometimes. On – then off – the buses It’s hard to keep up with transport firm FirstGroup’s view of its best strategy. Back in May, the “future emphasis” for the group was going to be First Student and First Transit, its two North American bus contractors, since they had “the greatest potential to generate sustainable value and growth over time”. Now both operations may be sold. What’s prompted the U-turn? One can point to the arrival of David Martin as chairman in August but, since he seemed to endorse the May vision only last month, the latest development looks to be a lobbying triumph for activist investor Coast Capital, aided these days by fellow investor Robert Tchenguiz. The duo demanded a sale of all US assets, not just the Greyhound coaching business, a few weeks ago; now they may get it. A UK-only future would be a mighty come-down for FirstGroup, which can currently call itself one of the world’s largest transport companies with 100,000 employees. Indeed, even within the UK, the future of the bus division is unclear, as FirstGroup is exploring what form of “separation” is possible while meeting pension obligations. If the buses were also to exit along with the US assets, all that would be left would be the UK rail business, from which FirstGroup seemed to be contemplating an orderly retreat only a year ago. Then it won the West Coast Partnership franchise and all is now apparently right with rail. One can view this strategic soul-searching as an exercise in “rationalisation”, the polite term for a break-up. It’s hard, though, to escape the feeling that there’s a simpler alternative to uncertain deal-making: just run the businesses better. Going up … ? Mike Ashley has been banging on about his “elevation” strategy for years and now he has something to show for it: a share price that elevated by 31% in a day. Context is everything, however.
a2_text:
Okay, here's the rewritten text, suitable for CEFR A2 level:

**Water Companies Need to Think**

Some water companies need to think carefully. These companies are Anglian, Northumbrian, Thames, and Yorkshire. People think these companies are good. They need to know that sometimes they will lose money. This is because they are private, but the government controls them.

**FirstGroup Changes its Mind**

FirstGroup is a company with buses and trains. It is hard to know what they want to do. In May, they said the future was in America. They have two bus companies there. They thought these companies would make a lot of money. But now, they might sell these American companies.

Why did they change their minds? David Martin is now the boss. He started in August. But he seemed to like the American companies last month.

Now, it looks like some people want to sell the American companies. These people are Coast Capital and Robert Tchenguiz. They asked FirstGroup to sell everything in America. Now, maybe they will.

If FirstGroup only has businesses in the UK, it will be smaller. FirstGroup is now one of the biggest transport companies in the world. It has 100,000 workers.

Even in the UK, the buses might be sold. FirstGroup is thinking about selling them. They need to pay money to old workers.

If they sell the buses and the American companies, they will only have trains in the UK. One year ago, they wanted to sell the trains too. But then they won a big train contract. Now, the trains are okay.

Maybe FirstGroup is trying to make things simpler. But maybe they should just try to do a better job with their businesses.

**Mike Ashley's Company is Doing Better**

Mike Ashley has talked about his plan for a long time. Now, his company is doing better. The price of his company's shares went up a lot in one day. The price went up 31%. But it is important to know why.

text: The improvement to 472p merely took the shares back to where they stood at the start of 2016, which is roughly when Ashley adopted his other obsession – diversification. House of Fraser, the main product of that ambition, clearly isn’t getting worse, which was why the shares jumped on Monday. But the eventual returns from the HoF deal remain a mystery. Ashley runs a tighter ship than the old management (no surprise there) but the long-term investment demands in the department store business are anyone’s guess.
a2_text:
Okay, here is the rewritten text at CEFR A2 level:

The shares went up to 472p. This is the same price as in 2016. In 2016, Ashley started to try new things with the company.

He wanted to try many different businesses. House of Fraser was one of them. It was his main idea.

House of Fraser is not getting worse. This is good news. So, the shares went up on Monday.

But we don't know if House of Fraser will make money in the future. It is still a secret.

Ashley is doing a better job than the old managers. That is not a surprise. But we don't know how much money House of Fraser will need in the long term. It is hard to guess.

text: With its army of perfectly groomed and manicured shop assistants, the department store beauty hall has traditionally been the backbone of a £2.5bn trade in expensive lipsticks, face creams or perfumes. But cosmetics sales have plummeted this year as high street shutdowns, coupled with the shift to home-working, has prompted many people to ditch their makeup bags. Sales of the designer brands sold via glossy counters in department stores are down by more than 40% this year, a decrease worth almost £500m, according to the market researcher NPD. The decline is even bigger if you throw in the £180m hit to sales of cheaper lipsticks and eyeshadows bought alongside groceries in supermarkets. Women are simply wearing less makeup, said Alexia Inge, the co-founder of the Cult Beauty website. “The lockdown expedited trends that were already happening. People were already starting to take a different approach to makeup from the Insta-glam layer-upon-layer [look].” The so-called “lipstick index” is often used as a barometer of consumer confidence during periods of economic turmoil. The term, which was coined by the former Estée Lauder chairman Leonard Lauder in the early 2000s, refers to the usual resiliency of cosmetics with makeup seen as an affordable indulgence when bigger purchases are out of reach. But the index never saw Covid-19 coming, with its mandatory face-coverings that mean no one can even see your lips, let alone what colour they are. During the lockdown, demand for products many would once have considered an essential part of their daily beauty routine – such as foundation and lipstick – was down by more than 70%. “Everyone likes to roll out Lauder’s lipstick effect … but lipstick sales are probably the worst of any category right now,” said Inge. Instead, she added, we should look at skincare, which is the “makeup equivalent” of the leisurewear people have been wearing at home during the pandemic. While Cult Beauty’s lipstick sales were down 8%, its skincare sales have more than doubled. This dramatic shift in spending priorities is borne out in figures from the department store chain John Lewis.
a2_text:
Big shops sell a lot of makeup. They have many shop workers who look very nice. They sell things like lipstick, cream for your face, and perfume. These things are usually expensive.

But this year, the shops have sold less makeup. The shops had to close because of the virus. Also, many people are working at home. So, people are not using as much makeup.

The makeup sold in big shops is down by 40%. This means the shops made less money. They lost about £500 million.

Even the cheaper makeup is selling less. The makeup sold in supermarkets is also down. This means the shops lost another £180 million.

Alexia Inge works for a website called Cult Beauty. She says that women are wearing less makeup. She says that the virus made this happen faster. People were already using less makeup before.

People often look at lipstick sales to see how the economy is doing. This is called the "lipstick index." When people cannot buy big things, they buy lipstick instead. Lipstick is a small treat.

But the virus changed everything. People need to wear masks. So, you cannot see their lips.

During the lockdown, people bought less makeup. They bought less foundation and lipstick. These things are usually part of their daily routine. The sales went down by 70%.

Alexia Inge says that lipstick sales are very bad right now. Instead, people are buying more skincare. Skincare is like the makeup version of clothes for relaxing at home.

Cult Beauty sold less lipstick, down by 8%. But they sold more than double the skincare products. People are spending their money on different things now.

The shop John Lewis also saw this change.

text: Its sales of skincare, body and hair products are up 234% this year, as people opt to spend time caring for their skin rather than applying makeup. John Lewis predicts some of the changes seen this year will stay around and that cosmetics bags will get smaller as women abandon lip pencils and contouring sticks – a hard-to-do blending technique popularised by Kim Kardashian – and switch to easy to use multipurpose products, such as tinted moisturiser and lip balm. Long periods at home have driven shoppers into the arms of Cult Beauty and its discount-driven Lookfantastic, which is part of The Hut Group founded by the billionaire Matthew Moulding. In common with other retail markets such as furniture, more than 40% of beauty sales will be online this year – almost double 2019’s level. The failure of a major player like Debenhams, with its 124 stores and 12,000 staff, is a fresh blow for the beauty industry left reeling by this year’s lengthy salon closures. Yes, times are tough for the high street, said June Jensen-Mills, the head of UK beauty at market researchers NPD, but store sales are likely to bounce back in 2021. “I believe that bricks and mortar will go back to being important,” she said. “People will want to meet up with friends, try things, have a coffee. Debenhams is an important player in the world of beauty but when a retailer closes customers shift to similar retailers where they feel at home.” There are also new powerful forces at work in the industry as the glitzy websites of blockbuster brands such as Charlotte Tilbury compete with the department stores that are also their business partners. For shoppers the joy of the beauty hall lies in the ability to discover new brands, trial out textures, test colours and sample scents, but coronavirus restrictions mean that is, in many cases, no longer possible. But department stores brands are fighting back with innovative new ways of selling, such as virtual masterclasses and compiling “discovery boxes” of sample-sized products. People seem to like it.
a2_text:
Sales of some beauty products are much higher this year. The sales are up 234%.
People are buying more skin care, body, and hair products. They want to take care of their skin. They are not using much makeup.

John Lewis thinks some changes will stay. People may not buy as much makeup in the future. Women may stop using some makeup products. For example, lip pencils and contouring sticks may not be popular. These makeup products are hard to use. Kim Kardashian made contouring popular. But now, women want easy products. They want to use things like tinted moisturiser and lip balm. These products do many things.

People have stayed home a lot. They are buying things from online stores. Two popular stores are Cult Beauty and Lookfantastic. Lookfantastic is owned by The Hut Group. Matthew Moulding started this group.

More beauty products are sold online this year. More than 40% of beauty sales are online. This is almost twice as much as in 2019. Other things, like furniture, are also sold online more often.

Debenhams was a big store. It had 124 stores and 12,000 workers. But it closed. This is bad for the beauty industry. Beauty salons were closed for a long time this year. This also hurt the industry.

June Jensen-Mills works for NPD. She studies the beauty market. She says it is a hard time for stores. But she thinks store sales will be better in 2021.

She believes stores will be important again. People will want to meet friends. They will want to try new products and have coffee. Debenhams was important. But now, people will go to other stores they like.

Big beauty brands have good websites. For example, Charlotte Tilbury has a website. These brands sell products on their websites. They also sell products in stores. So, they are competing with the stores.

People like to find new beauty brands in stores. They like to try the products. They can test colors and smells. But now, it is hard to do this because of the virus.

Department stores are trying new ways to sell things. They are having online classes. They are also making boxes with small samples of products. People seem to like these new ways.

text: Last week John Lewis and Charlotte Tilbury broke the Guinness World Records’ title for the UK’s largest ever beauty masterclass after 10,000 people signed up to “brush along at home” to create a “timeless 90s supermodel-inspired look”. Consumers may be looking for “simplicity” now but their feelings may change in 2021. “I have a strong feeling that once we come out of lockdown, and the bars and discos are open again, things will pick up,” said Jensen-Mills. “People will think ‘I’ve had an awful year and I want to make myself feel and look great’. Let’s just slap on loads of foundation and lipstick.”
a2_text:
Last week, John Lewis and Charlotte Tilbury did something special. They had a big beauty class.
Many people joined the class. Ten thousand people learned how to do makeup.
It was the biggest beauty class in the UK ever!
They broke a record from Guinness World Records.
People learned how to make a “90s supermodel” look.
They did their makeup at home with the class.

Now, people want makeup to be easy.
But things might change next year, in 2021.
Someone named Jensen-Mills said that things will get better.
She thinks that when lockdown ends, people will go out again.
They will go to bars and discos.
People will want to feel good.
They will want to look good.
They might use a lot of makeup!
Maybe lots of foundation and lipstick!

text: Toyota will stop production at its British and French plants earlier than scheduled before Christmas because of the chaos caused by Covid-19 border closures. The Japanese carmaker said it was expecting shortages of parts as a result of transport delays, after France’s 48-hour ban on accompanied freight or cargo from Britain led to queues of lorries miles long stuck near Dover. Toyota said it had decided to bring forward the “planned seasonal stop” at its engine plant in Deeside in north Wales and its factory at Burnaston in Derbyshire, where it makes the Corolla. About 3,000 people are employed at the two plants. The Deeside site will close for Christmas on Tuesday and the Burnaston plant on Wednesday. Its French site will also stop production two days earlier than planned. The European factories would ordinarily have closed for an annual shutdown on Christmas Eve and remained shut until 4 January. Toyota said it wanted to “help ensure the safety and security of our employees and all our stakeholders, particularly our logistics partners and in consideration of society’s wider needs”. The car manufacturer said it had taken the decision “in light of the traffic bans that a growing number of countries have issued for travel from the UK and due to the uncertain nature of how long the borders will be closed for logistics activities”. The extended shutdown caps a tumultuous year for the automotive industry, which halted production in the spring as the first wave of the pandemic took hold. The French government is expected to make an announcement on Tuesday about reopening transport links with the UK. Paris failed to lift its 48-hour ban on freight and passengers from Britain over fears about the new coronavirus strain, despite a phone call on Monday evening between Boris Johnson and Emmanuel Macron. France is one of more than 40 countries that have suspended flights and trains from the UK, including Denmark, Germany, Italy, Belgium, Ireland, Turkey and Canada. However, the suspension of cross-Channel transport has caused the most disruption in and around British ports, which were already struggling with increased workloads because of the arrival of Christmas goods, companies stockpiling ahead of Brexit and coronavirus restrictions.
a2_text:
Toyota will stop making cars in Britain and France. This will happen sooner than planned because of problems with Covid-19.

The borders are closed. This is causing problems for Toyota. They think they will not have enough car parts. This is because trucks are delayed.

France stopped trucks from Britain for two days. This made long lines of trucks near Dover. Dover is a place in England.

Toyota will stop working at its factory in Wales. It will also stop working at its factory in England. They make car engines in Wales. They make Corolla cars in England.

About 3,000 people work at these two factories. The factory in Wales will close on Tuesday. The factory in England will close on Wednesday. The factory in France will also close early.

Usually, the factories close for Christmas on Christmas Eve. They open again on January 4. But this year, they will close earlier.

Toyota wants to keep its workers safe. They also want to help the people who bring them parts. They want to help everyone.

Many countries have stopped travel from Britain. This is because of the border problems. Toyota does not know when the borders will open again.

This year has been hard for car companies. They stopped making cars in the spring. This was because of Covid-19.

France will say something about opening the borders. This will happen on Tuesday.

France did not open the borders. They are worried about a new type of coronavirus. The leaders of Britain and France talked on the phone. But France still did not open the borders.

Many countries have stopped planes and trains from Britain. These countries include Denmark, Germany, Italy, Belgium, Ireland, Turkey, and Canada.

The border problems are causing big problems in Britain. The ports are very busy. They have a lot of Christmas goods. Companies are also storing things because of Brexit. Brexit is when Britain leaves the European Union. Coronavirus is also making things difficult.

text: Shaftesbury, one of the biggest landlords in central London, has slumped to a £700m loss after slashing the value of its portfolio, as the West End braces for tougher Covid-19 restrictions. The company, which owns parts of Chinatown, Soho and Covent Garden, has been hit by the sharp fall in the number of tourists and office workers coming into the capital. It said vacancies at its shops, restaurants and offices had nearly tripled to 10.2% in the year to 30 September. As tenants struggled to pay their rent, Shaftesbury’s net income fell by 24% to £74.3 . It collected only 53% of the rent due in the second half of the year. This resulted in an annual loss after tax of £699.5m, compared with a profit of £26m the previous year. Shaftesbury wrote down the value of its portfolio by 18.3% to £3.1bn, as the amount of empty space in the West End increased, rental income fell and physical distancing measures reduced demand from retail and office tenants for more space. Brian Bickell, the Shaftesbury chief executive, said: “Rarely in history has the world seen such widespread disruption to normal patterns of life. Only now are we seeing the first positive signs that conditions will begin to improve in the year ahead.” Shaftesbury said its leasing activity had declined sharply since February due to the pandemic and was below normal levels, although there had been a pickup in inquiries in recent weeks. The pandemic has also forced landlords to rewrite lease agreements to help tenants get through the crisis, and Shaftesbury moved permanently to monthly rents for most commercial tenants from October. The company said its rental and service charge support for tenants was likely to continue through 2021, “with our occupiers having reduced income in the important period leading up to Christmas and into the new year, which traditionally has provided them with liquidity buffers to withstand the normally slower quarter to March”. London is among the areas that enter tier 3 restrictions on Wednesday, which means hotels, pubs, bars and restaurants have to close again and can only do takeaways and deliver. Shaftesbury gave a gloomy outlook for next year, predicting that pandemic control measures were “likely for much of 2021”.
a2_text:
Shaftesbury is a big owner of buildings in London. They own buildings in places like Chinatown, Soho and Covent Garden.

They have lost a lot of money. They lost £700 million. This is because their buildings are worth less now.

The West End in London is getting ready for harder rules because of Covid-19.

Not many tourists and office workers are coming to London. This is a problem for Shaftesbury.

Many of their shops, restaurants and offices are empty. Almost three times more are empty than before. 10.2% of their buildings are empty.

It is hard for the people renting their buildings to pay. Shaftesbury made less money. Their money went down by 24% to £74.3 million.

They only got 53% of the rent money that they should have.

They lost £699.5 million this year. Last year, they made £26 million.

The buildings are worth less now. They are worth 18.3% less. Now they are worth £3.1 billion.

There are more empty spaces in the West End. They get less money for rent. People need more space between them. This means shops and offices do not need as much space.

The boss of Shaftesbury, Brian Bickell, said things are very bad now. But he thinks things will get better soon.

Shaftesbury is not renting buildings as much as before. This started in February because of the virus. But now, more people are asking about renting.

The virus has made Shaftesbury change the rent rules. They are helping the people who rent from them. Shaftesbury now asks for rent every month for most shops and offices.

Shaftesbury will keep helping the people who rent from them in 2021. The people who rent will not make as much money before Christmas and New Year. This is a hard time for them.

London is going into stricter rules. This means hotels, pubs, bars and restaurants must close again. They can only sell takeaway food and deliver food.

Shaftesbury thinks next year will be bad too. They think the virus rules will stay for a long time in 2021.

text: Even so, the firm was confident in the West End’s long-term ability to attract visitors. Bickell said: “In the year ahead, the widespread distribution of effective vaccines will bring a gradual return of confidence and activity across the West End and, a recovery in domestic footfall and spending to our villages. “At the present time, it is not possible to predict at what point conditions will improve but it is likely social distancing and other restrictions, with the risk of further lockdowns, will continue into the spring and possibly early summer, putting further financial strain on many of our occupiers.”
a2_text:
The company believed in the West End. They thought it would have many visitors again.

Mr. Bickell said something about this. He said that vaccines will help. The vaccines will help people feel safe again. People will start going to the West End again.

More people from the country will come. They will spend money in the shops.

But we don't know when things will get better. Maybe we will still need to stay away from each other. Maybe some places will close again. This could happen in the spring. Maybe it will last until summer.

This will be hard for the shops and businesses. They will have money problems.

text: Britain’s economy is suffering increasing damage from the rapid growth in Covid infections, renewed lockdown measures, and turmoil over Brexit at the end of the worst year for growth in three centuries, according to a Guardian analysis. With negotiations going down to the wire amid vast tailbacks at Dover before the Brexit transition expires on New Year’s Eve, the latest figures from the UK economy show stalling growth, falling retail sales, and redundancies rising at the fastest rate since records began. In a month that started with a burst of optimism as a British woman became the first patient in the world to receive the coronavirus vaccine, December is ending with the pandemic surging to a fresh peak and Boris Johnson’s government imposing tougher lockdown measures before Christmas. To counter the emergence of a faster-spreading Covid variant in the UK, and as Brexit talks intensify, the French ban on freight movements has led to chaos in Kent days before a no-deal Brexit could trigger renewed turmoil. Official figures had shown the British economy recovered from lockdown this spring at a faster rate than first anticipated, amid hopes that a vaccine could bring an early end to the crisis. However, economists now forecast a double-dip recession and tougher lockdowns lasting into 2021 before the vaccine can be rolled out widely enough. David Blanchflower, a former member of the Bank of England’s rate-setting monetary policy committee, said Brexit – with or without a trade deal with Brussels – would hit an already weak UK economy at the start of next year. Writing in the Guardian, he said: “It does seem to me to be the worst decision in peacetime any country in the world has made in a thousand years. Lines of lorries at Dover and Folkestone do not augur well for what is to come, even before Boris Johnson cancelled Christmas.” Since the onset of the pandemic, the Guardian has chosen eight economic indicators, as well as the level of the FTSE 100, to track the impact on jobs and growth from Covid-19 and the measures used to contain it. Faced with the deepest global recession since the Great Depression, the Covid crisis watch also monitors how the UK is faring compared with other countries.
a2_text:
Okay, here is the rewritten text at a CEFR A2 level:

Britain's economy is having problems. COVID-19 infections are growing fast. There are new rules because of the virus. Brexit is also causing problems. This year has been the worst for the economy in 300 years.

Brexit talks are happening now. There are long lines of trucks at Dover. Brexit will happen on New Year's Eve. The UK economy is not growing. Shops are selling less. More people are losing their jobs. This is the fastest rate ever.

December started with good news. A British woman got the first COVID-19 vaccine. But now, the virus is getting worse. The government is making new rules before Christmas.

A new type of COVID-19 is spreading quickly in the UK. Brexit talks are hard. France stopped trucks from coming to the UK. This made problems in Kent. A "no-deal" Brexit could cause more problems.

The British economy got better after the lockdown in the spring. It got better faster than expected. People hoped the vaccine would end the crisis soon. But now, experts think the economy will get worse again. There will be more lockdowns in 2021. The vaccine will take time to give to everyone.

David Blanchflower used to work for the Bank of England. He said Brexit will hurt the UK economy. It does not matter if there is a deal with Europe or not. He wrote in the Guardian newspaper. He said Brexit is a very bad decision for the country. He said the lines of trucks at Dover are a bad sign. This was even before the Prime Minister cancelled Christmas.

The Guardian newspaper is watching the economy. They are looking at eight things to see how COVID-19 is affecting jobs and the economy. They also look at the FTSE 100. COVID-19 has caused a big problem for the world economy. The Guardian is also watching how the UK is doing compared to other countries.

text: In the past month, there have been some bright spots for the economy, including a recovery in business activity in early December after the second national lockdown in England. Tougher restrictions in the autumn appear to have had less of an impact on growth and jobs than during the first wave of the pandemic. Official figures show Britain’s economy staged a faster recovery in the third quarter of the year than was first estimated, after a rapid return to work after the first lockdown. However, official growth figures also show the economy started sinking towards a double-dip recession even before Covid restrictions were reimposed in November. The Bank of England has warned the economy will shrink in the final months of 2020 and could remain weaker than expected at the start of 2021, as controls are kept in place to handle rising infections before the Covid vaccine can be rolled out widely. In response to the renewed period of economic pain, the chancellor, Rishi Sunak, unexpectedly extended the furlough scheme until the end of April, a month longer than planned. Use of the flagship wage subsidy programme, which has cost the government almost £50bn so far, doubled in November to about 5 million workers, reflects the intense pressure facing companies. Sunak announced plans to hold a budget on 3 March to set out the next stage of the government’s economic response to the pandemic. However, business groups and Labour have warned additional support is required to support firms and workers during a period of extended lockdown restrictions. The number of people being made redundant reached a record high in October, at a time when the government was winding down furlough before a last-minute U-turn to extend the scheme. Unemployment is expected to hit 2.6 million next year when the scheme ends. Blanchflower said: “The issue is whether these jobs – many in pubs, clubs and restaurants – return after the furlough payments stop. But many jobs won’t return, if there are long-run changes in behaviour after the pandemic as expected.”
a2_text:
Here is the rewritten text at CEFR A2 level:

The economy has had some good news lately. Businesses started to do better in December. This was after the second lockdown in England.

The rules in autumn did not hurt the economy as much as before. Official numbers show that the economy got better faster in the summer. People went back to work quickly after the first lockdown.

But the numbers also show that the economy started to get worse again before November. This was before the new rules about Covid.

The Bank of England said the economy will get smaller at the end of the year. It may stay weak in early 2021. This is because there will still be rules to stop Covid from spreading. People need to wait for the vaccine.

The government knows that businesses are having problems again. So, the government will help pay workers until the end of April. This is longer than planned.

This help for workers is costing the government a lot of money. In November, many more people needed this help. About five million workers got money. This shows that companies are having a hard time.

The government will talk about the economy on March 3. They will say what they will do to help with the pandemic.

Some groups say that more help is needed now. They want to help businesses and workers while the rules are in place.

In October, many people lost their jobs. This was when the government was going to stop helping pay workers. But then they changed their mind and gave more help.

Next year, many people may not have jobs. About 2.6 million people could be without work. This is when the help for workers stops.

One person said that some jobs may not come back. These jobs are in places like pubs and restaurants. He thinks people may change their habits after the pandemic. So, some jobs may disappear.

text: The former owner of Norton Motorcycles will be forced to pay back about £14m missing from the company’s employee retirement fund, after being refused permission to appeal against a pensions ombudsman’s ruling. Stuart Garner, who acquired the classic marque in 2008 and was feted for years by a series of UK government ministers, was told by the regulator in June to refund three retirement funds he controlled as trustee, following an ombudsman ruling that he had acted dishonestly. The ombudsman’s decision followed an investigation triggered by claims brought by 30 members that Garner had repeatedly failed to return their funds when they were due. The Pension Schemes Act requires trustees to transfer pensions within six months of an application. The court’s refusal to entertain Garner’s request to appeal is another blow for the businessman, who appears to have been pushed a step closer to personal bankruptcy. He is already the subject of a personal bankruptcy petition filed by Leicester city council. The repayment of the £14m to the pension holders, the vast majority of whom were never Norton employees, had been on hold while the court considered Garner’s request for permission to appeal. In an August order delaying the payment, Mr Justice Fancourt said: “The sum likely to be payable … is extremely large and it is readily understandable that [Garner] will not be able to pay it and that, as a result, he is liable to be made bankrupt.” In his latest judgment refusing an appeal, however, Fancourt stated: “There could have been no good reason to delay the payment of compensation unless there was compelling evidence that it would be provided by other means within the timescale specified by the ombudsman.” Garner has been granted permission to appeal against a further £180,000 in distress payments to 30 of the scheme’s 228 members, to whom he had repeatedly failed to return funds when they were due. The businessman’s law firm said: “Mr Garner has been granted permission to appeal the inconvenience award, and has renewed his application for permission to appeal in respect of the refusal.” Garner, who was the trustee of three Norton pension funds, invested all of the members’ savings into his own company, but Norton slumped into administration on 29 January.
a2_text:
A man used to own a company called Norton Motorcycles. He must now pay back money. This money is for the company's worker's retirement fund. The amount is about £14 million.

He asked if he could change a decision about this money. But he was told no. He cannot change the decision.

The man is named Stuart Garner. He bought Norton Motorcycles in 2008. Many important people in the UK liked him for this.

In June, someone told him to give the money back. He was in charge of the retirement funds. He was the trustee. The person said he did not act honestly.

This happened after people said they did not get their money back. About 30 people said this. They should have gotten their money.

There is a law. This law says the trustee must give the money back in six months.

The court said no to Stuart Garner's request. This is bad for him. He may now have to say he has no money. This is called bankruptcy.

A city council already asked the court to say he has no money.

He needs to pay back £14 million. Most of the people who should get this money never worked for Norton. The payment was stopped while the court thought about his request.

Someone named Mr. Justice Fancourt said the money is a lot. He said Stuart Garner probably cannot pay it. He might have to say he has no money.

Mr. Justice Fancourt said there was no good reason to wait. He said the money should be paid quickly.

Stuart Garner can still ask to change another decision. This is about £180,000. This money is for 30 people. He did not give them their money when he should have.

His lawyers said he can still appeal about some money. He also wants to appeal the first decision again.

Stuart Garner was in charge of the Norton pension funds. He put all the workers' money into his own company. But Norton Motorcycles had problems. It closed on January 29.

text: The ombudsman’s determination in the summer stated: “The trustee has acted dishonestly and in breach of his duty of no conflict, his duty not to profit and his duty to act with prudence.” The decision followed a Guardian and ITV News investigation in January that showed how 228 “ordinary working people” had had their entire pension pots invested into Norton shares after they had been duped by a fraudster. Garner received the retirement savings during 2012 and 2013, after a scam that resulted in a promoter, Simon Colfer, being convicted of fraud in 2018 for the way he had sold the scheme. Two further Garner associates involved in setting up the Norton pensions schemes, Andrew Meeson and Peter Bradley, were convicted of a separate tax fraud in 2013, when they reclaimed £5m of tax rebates from fictitious pension contributions. Court documents from that trial show that £990,000 of the fraud proceeds were loaned to Garner to acquire Norton in 2008. Garner denies wrongdoing and has said he considers himself a victim because he did not know he was dealing with fraudsters.
a2_text:
Here is the text rewritten for CEFR A2 level:

The ombudsman said something in the summer. He said the trustee did bad things. The trustee was not honest. He did not do his job well. He used the money in a wrong way.

This happened after an investigation. The Guardian and ITV News looked into it in January. They found that many people lost their pensions. These were normal, working people. They had 228 pensions. The pensions were all put into Norton shares. Someone tricked these people. A bad person cheated them.

Garner got the pension money. This was in 2012 and 2013. Someone had tricked people to give the money. A man named Simon Colfer sold the plan. He was a fraudster. He was found guilty of fraud in 2018.

Two other people helped Garner. They were Andrew Meeson and Peter Bradley. They helped set up the Norton pensions. They also did something wrong. They took tax money in 2013. They said they paid money into pensions, but they did not. They took £5 million.

The court looked at these things. The court papers said that Garner got money. He got £990,000. This money was from the fraud. He used it to buy Norton in 2008.

Garner says he did not do anything wrong. He says he is also a victim. He says he did not know the others were bad people. He did not know they were fraudsters.

text: Black, Asian and minority ethnic (BAME) people are much more likely than white people to work in hospitality, one of the sectors hardest hit by the economic fallout of the pandemic as restaurants, bars and other venues have been shut for months during the lockdowns. About one in 12 (8%) workers from BAME backgrounds are employed in hospitality roles. That compares with about one in 20 (5%) white British workers, research from the Resolution Foundation shows. Overall, 300,000 people from BAME backgrounds work in hospitality. The thinktank’s report found that even before the pandemic hit, hospitality was one of the lowest paying sectors in the economy, with a typical hourly pay of £8.72. It said that 23% of hospitality workers were paid at or below the national living wage. The research found that BAME workers in the sector also faced “pay penalties” – pay gaps that account for workers’ age, qualifications, experience, and the kinds of jobs they do – relative to white British workers. “Crucially, these pay penalties are bigger than the raw pay gaps found in official earnings data – suggesting that the extent of disadvantage is bigger than previously thought,” the report said. BAME men were paid 65p an hour less than white British men on average, the report found. BAME women were also underpaid compared with white British women but the gap was less severe. The report found that while hospitality as a whole disproportionately employed young people – over a third of its workforce were aged 16-24 – this was not always the case for BAME workers. For example, the typical age of a Bangladeshi worker in hospitality was 42 – higher than the typical age for Bangladeshi workers across the whole economy (35), and higher than white British workers in hospitality (28). Indian workers in hospitality were among the highest paid ethnic group per hour (£8.96) and among the most likely to be in high-paying occupations (28%) such as hotel and restaurant managers. This corresponds with 41% of Indian hospitality workers holding a degree. In comparison, one in four Bangladeshi hospitality workers had no qualifications and typically earned 12% less than Indian hospitality workers, at £7.85 an hour.
a2_text:
People of color are more likely to work in hotels and restaurants. These people are Black, Asian, or from another ethnic group. We call them BAME.

Hotels and restaurants are having problems now. This is because of the pandemic. Many places are closed.

Eight out of 100 BAME workers work in hotels and restaurants. Only five out of 100 white British workers work there. This information comes from a study.

About 300,000 BAME people work in hotels and restaurants.

The study also said that hotels and restaurants did not pay much. Before the pandemic, people got about £8.72 per hour. This is not a lot of money.

About 23 out of 100 workers in hotels and restaurants got very low pay. This pay was at or below the national living wage.

BAME workers also had problems with their pay. They got less money than white British workers. This was true even when they had the same age, skills, and jobs.

The study said that BAME people had more problems than we thought. They were paid less than white British people.

BAME men got 65p less per hour than white British men. BAME women also got less money than white British women. But the difference was smaller.

Many young people work in hotels and restaurants. More than a third of workers are between 16 and 24 years old. But this is not always true for BAME workers.

For example, many Bangladeshi workers in hotels and restaurants are older. The average age is 42. This is older than Bangladeshi workers in other jobs. It is also older than white British workers in hotels and restaurants.

Indian workers in hotels and restaurants got more money. They earned about £8.96 per hour. Many of them had good jobs, like managers.

Many Indian workers had a degree. About 41 out of 100 had a degree.

Bangladeshi workers often had no qualifications. About 25 out of 100 had no qualifications. They got less money than Indian workers. They earned about £7.85 per hour.

text: Nye Cominetti, the senior economist at the Resolution Foundation, said: “As workers from BAME backgrounds are disproportionately likely to work in hospitality, a significant number of workers risk moving into unemployment when the furlough scheme ends in the spring. “The government should bear that in mind for the jobs support programmes it is providing.” A report by the British Beer & Pubs Association and the consultancy Oxford Economics has previously warned that 291,000 jobs in the hospitality trade could be lost as a result of coronavirus restrictions. The forecast was based on industry data suggesting that 25% of pubs could close, with the remainder barely breaking even as they struggle to cope with reduced custom and limited opening hours. Oxford Economics said the worst-case scenario would reduce the sector’s economic output by £7.4bn and cut wages by £3.9bn.
a2_text:
Here is the text rewritten for CEFR A2 level English:

Nye Cominetti works at the Resolution Foundation. He is an important economist there. He said something about jobs.

Many workers from BAME groups work in hospitality. BAME means Black, Asian, and Minority Ethnic. Hospitality is work like in restaurants and hotels. These workers may lose their jobs. This could happen when the furlough scheme ends. The furlough scheme helps pay workers during the pandemic. It ends in the spring.

Nye Cominetti thinks the government should remember this. The government has job support programs. These programs help people find work.

A report said that many jobs could be lost. The British Beer & Pubs Association and Oxford Economics wrote the report. They said coronavirus rules could cause job losses. About 291,000 jobs could be lost in hospitality.

The report said that some pubs might close. Twenty-five percent of pubs could close. The other pubs might not make much money. They have fewer customers. They cannot open for many hours.

Oxford Economics said the situation could be very bad. The economy could lose a lot of money. Wages could go down by £3.9 billion. The sector's output could be reduced by £7.4 billion.

text: Family-owned Welsh brewer SA Brain & Co has handed over the running of its 156 pubs to Marston’s, saving 1,300 jobs, after the coronavirus pandemic threatened their closure. Brains, whose pubs are mainly based in south and west Wales, said it had come “under significant financial pressure” during the pandemic, as restrictions mean pubs must remain closed except for takeaway and delivery. The company closed its entire pub estate on 4 December after the announcement of a ban on alcohol sales and enforced 6pm closing across Wales to try to contain a worsening Covid-19 outbreak. Remaining open under those restrictions was “not a viable option”, Brains said. SA Brain & Co was established in 1882 in Cardiff, and became Wales’s biggest brewer and pubs company while remaining under family ownership. John Rhys, the company chairman who oversaw the deal, is the great-grandson of founder Samuel Arthur Brain. Before the pandemic, the pubs included in the deal made £14m a year in core earnings. Marston’s will take over the pubs in February, mostly under 25-year leases from Brains. The annual rent on the pubs was £5.5m. The pubs will be run under the Brains brand, and will continue to sell its beer, which is brewed at a facility in Cardiff Bay that was opened in March 2019. Before that Brains was made in breweries in Cardiff’s city centre. Rhys said: “We know and trust Marston’s to be excellent custodians of our pubs and, while this is not a decision we have taken lightly, we are confident that our pubs and our pubs teams will thrive under their stewardship. “Furthermore, this transaction enables Brains to recapitalise its balance sheet and continue its long heritage as an independent entity, preserving this great Welsh business for generations to come.” Marston’s, formerly known as Wolverhampton and Dudley Breweries until a 2007 rebrand, runs about 1,400 pubs across the UK, including 106 in Wales. The 1,300 employees in Brains pubs will transfer to Marston’s, which employs a further 14,000 people across the UK.
a2_text:
A Welsh company called SA Brain & Co owns many pubs. These pubs are mostly in south and west Wales. The company is owned by a family.

Because of the coronavirus, the pubs had to close. People could only buy drinks and food to take away. This made it hard for the company to make money.

The company was having money problems. They needed to save the jobs of 1,300 people. So, they decided to let another company run their pubs.

The other company is called Marston's. Marston's will now run the 156 Brains pubs.

Brains said it was hard for them because pubs had to close early at 6 p.m. and could not sell alcohol.

SA Brain & Co started in 1882. It became the biggest beer and pubs company in Wales. The family still owned it.

John Rhys is the chairman of the company. He is the great-grandson of the person who started the company. His name was Samuel Arthur Brain.

Before the coronavirus, the pubs made a lot of money. They made £14 million each year.

Marston's will start running the pubs in February. They will rent the pubs from Brains for 25 years. The rent will be £5.5 million each year.

The pubs will still be called Brains pubs. They will still sell Brains beer. The beer is made in Cardiff Bay. The factory there opened in 2019. Before that, the beer was made in Cardiff city centre.

John Rhys said that Marston's will take good care of the pubs. He trusts them. He is happy that the pubs and the people who work there will do well with Marston's.

He also said that this deal will help Brains with their money problems. Brains can stay a Welsh company for a long time.

Marston's used to be called Wolverhampton and Dudley Breweries. They changed their name in 2007. Marston's runs about 1,400 pubs in the UK. 106 of these pubs are in Wales.

The 1,300 people who work in the Brains pubs will now work for Marston's. Marston's has 14,000 workers in the UK already.

text: Ralph Findlay, the Marston’s chief executive, said the deal would be mutually beneficial and that it “strengthens our representation in south and west Wales, while protecting the heritage and independence of an iconic Welsh business”.
a2_text:
Ralph Findlay is the boss of Marston's. He said the deal is good for both companies.

He said it will help Marston's in south and west Wales.

It will also protect an old Welsh business. This business is very important in Wales. It will stay independent.

text: Britain’s independent shops had a sales boost in 2020 despite an overall drop in retail spending, as Covid travel restrictions and working from home prompted consumers to shop on local high streets instead of city centres. Data from Barclaycard shows spending at independent food and drink shops, including off-licences, butchers and bakeries, jumped 28.6% in 2020 compared with a year earlier. In contrast, total consumer spending fell 7.1%, as social distancing rules left shoppers with fewer opportunities to spend on overseas holidays, hospitality and in city centres. Barclaycard, which covers nearly half of the UK’s credit and debit card transactions, found that while spending on essential goods such as groceries rose by 4.1% compared with 2019, non-essential spending fell 11.3%. Department stores were particularly hard hit, with spending down 17.2%, while clothing retailers experienced a 15.6% slump, leading to the financial problems at the likes of Debenhams and the Topshop owner, Arcadia. However, bricks and mortar discounters had a 25.4% increase, as Britons facing furlough and job cuts sought value for money deals. Consumers forced to spend more time at home turned to DIY projects to spruce up their living space. Pent-up demand after the reopening of non-essential shops in June pushed overall spending at DIY and home goods stores up 9.8% for the year. Furniture retailers reported a 5.3% rise, as consumers invested in big ticket items. Britons treated themselves – as well as friends and family they could not see – to flowers throughout the year, with spending at florists rising 22.7%. Crafts and hobby spending increased 9.8%, and pets were given extra attention with vet and pet retail increasing 10.7%. But the report also shows how much restaurants suffered despite Rishi Sunak’s “eat out to help out” initiative over the summer. Restrictions throughout the rest of the year contributed to a 47% drop in restaurant spending, while bars and pubs took a 36.7% hit. However, Covid restrictions contributed to a 49.1% rise in spending on online takeaway orders, while meal subscription services jumped 62.4%. Demand for at-home entertainment pushed spending on digital subscriptions up 31.5%, while money spent on electronics including game consoles rose 10.8%.
a2_text:
In 2020, there was a virus called Covid. People could not travel easily. Many people worked from home.

Because of this, shops in local areas did better. They sold more things. But shops in big cities did not do so well.

Barclaycard has some information. It shows that small food shops sold more. These shops include places that sell drinks, meat, and bread. They sold 28.6% more than the year before.

But in total, people spent less money. They spent 7.1% less. This is because they could not go on holidays or go to city centers.

Barclaycard looked at many payments. They found that people spent more on important things like food. This went up by 4.1%. But they spent less on things they did not need. This went down by 11.3%.

Big shops that sell many things did not do well. Their sales went down by 17.2%. Clothes shops also had problems. Their sales went down by 15.6%. Some of these shops had money problems.

But shops with cheap prices did well. Their sales went up by 25.4%. This is because many people lost their jobs. They wanted to find good deals.

People stayed home more. So, they did projects in their houses. They bought things to make their homes look nicer. Shops that sold these things sold 9.8% more than before.

Shops that sold furniture also did well. Their sales went up by 5.3%. People bought new things for their homes.

People also bought flowers for themselves and for friends. They could not see their friends, so they sent flowers. Flower shops sold 22.7% more flowers.

People spent more money on hobbies. This went up by 9.8%. They also spent more money on their pets. Shops for pets and vets sold 10.7% more.

But restaurants did not do well. The government tried to help them with a plan. But restaurants still sold 47% less than before. Bars and pubs also sold 36.7% less.

But people bought more takeaway food online. This went up by 49.1%. People also bought meal subscriptions. This went up by 62.4%.

People wanted to have fun at home. So, they spent more money on things like Netflix. This went up by 31.5%. They also bought more game consoles. This went up by 10.8%.

text: Meanwhile, general online retailers benefited from a 52.5% hike in spending. Raheel Ahmed, Barclaycard’s head of consumer products, said: “2020 has accelerated many trends. E-commerce has seen huge growth, working from home has meant many are shopping more locally, and experiences within the home, such as virtual workouts, have become the norm.” Travel spending, including on airlines and travel agents, tumbled 61.1% in August and 63.1% in September, as coronavirus restrictions and quarantine rules took their toll. “Hopefully with a vaccine being rolled out in 2021 we will see green shoots for the most severely impacted sectors,” Ahmed said. “Having said that, some of the trends and changes we have seen in customer habits may be here to stay.”
a2_text:
Online shops did very well. People spent 52% more money in these shops.

Raheel Ahmed works for Barclaycard. He said that many things changed in 2020.

More people are buying things online. This is because they are working from home.

People also do more things at home. For example, they do exercise online.

Travel spending went down a lot. People spent less money on planes and travel agents. This is because of the coronavirus. It went down 61% in August and 63% in September. It was hard to travel.

Raheel Ahmed hopes for a vaccine in 2021. He thinks this will help the travel business.

But he also thinks some things will not change. People may still buy more things online. These new habits might stay.

text: The plus-size clothing brand Evans has been bought out of administration in a £23m deal that will result in the closure of all its stores and concessions with the potential loss of hundreds of jobs . The chain is the first part of Sir Philip Green’s Arcadia Group to be sold off, marking the beginning of the breakup of his fashion empire, which also includes Topshop, Dorothy Perkins, Burton and Miss Selfridge. City Chic Collective, an Australian retailer, plans to operate Evans, which made sales of £26m online and via wholesale last year, as an online-only brand. That will mean the closure of more than 100 Evans concessions and outlets within other Arcadia stores. Five standalone stores will permanently close with the loss of 25 jobs. The concessions and other outlets will not close immediately but hundreds of jobs are at risk at those outlets. Arcadia, which employs 13,000 people at about 500 outlets, collapsed into administration last month as high street lockdowns prompted by the coronavirus pandemic piled on pressure after years of flagging sales amid heavy competition from rivals such as Boohoo and Primark. Bids for all the brands are due to be filed on Monday, with Topshop expected to attract offers of up to £200m. Bidders are thought to include the online specialist Boohoo, the fashion and homewares group Next, and Authentic Brands, the owner of the US department store Barneys. Mike Ashley’s Frasers Group, formerly known as Sports Direct, is also thought to be interested in the smaller Arcadia brands. Administrators from Deloitte said on Monday there had been “significant expressions of interest for all brands”. They said they did not expect to provide a further update on the process until January. City Chic Collective said it had bought Evans as part of a plan to extend its portfolio of plus-size brands, which include City Chic and Hips & Curves, into Europe. It operates in Australia, New Zealand and the US, where it bought the Avenue brand last year. The company already had a relationship with Evans, which has sold City Chic products via its website for the past five years. “Our vision has always been to lead a world of curves,” said Phil Ryan, the chief executive of City Chic Collective.
